## How Long Does Measles‑Containing Vaccine (MMR) Protect a Child? | Question | Answer backed by the scientific literature | |----------|--------------------------------------------| | **What is the recommended schedule?** | • **First dose** at **12‑15 months** of age.
• **Second dose** at **4‑6 years** (or earlier if the child will be entering school/day‑care). The second dose is not a “booster” because most children have already made antibodies after the first dose; it is given to catch the small minority (≈ 2‑5 %) who did **not** develop immunity the first time. | | **How durable is the protection after the two‑dose series?** | • **Serologic studies** show that ≥ 97 % of children who receive both doses have protective measles IgG titers that persist for **decades**.
• **Long‑term cohort data**: In the United States, people who received two doses in childhood still have protective titers > 30 years later (e.g., a 2018 CDC review of > 10 000 adults aged 18‑50 y showed 99 % seropositivity).
• **World Health Organization (WHO) position**: “Two doses of measles‑containing vaccine provide **lifelong immunity** for the vast majority of recipients; no routine adult booster is recommended in countries with high coverage.” | | **Are there documented cases of waning immunity?** | • **Rare**. A handful of outbreak investigations have identified **vaccine‑failure** cases in adolescents or adults who received two doses, usually linked to **primary vaccine failure** (the child never responded) rather than waning.
• In **high‑incidence settings** where many adults were never vaccinated, measles can re‑appear, but in countries with ≥ 95 % two‑dose coverage, **secondary failure** (loss of immunity after an initially good response) is **exceptionally uncommon** (< 1 case per 1 million vaccinees). | | **What about people with weakened immune systems?** | • The MMR vaccine is **live‑attenuated**; it is **contra‑indicated** for individuals with severe immunodeficiency (e.g., chemotherapy, advanced HIV, primary immune‑deficiency disorders).
• For those who are **moderately immunocompromised** (e.g., low‑dose steroids), clinicians weigh the risk of disease versus the theoretical risk of vaccine‑related infection; most guidelines still recommend vaccination because measles can be far more dangerous. | | **Bottom line** | **Two doses of MMR give essentially lifelong protection for > 95 % of healthy children.** A third dose is only considered in special circumstances (e.g., during a large outbreak in a highly vaccinated population, or for certain high‑risk occupational groups). | --- ## Common Side Effects Parents Usually See | Side‑effect | Frequency (per 100 doses) | Typical course (duration) | How to manage it | |-------------|---------------------------|---------------------------|------------------| | **Pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site** | 1–5 % (often less for subcutaneous MMR) | 1‑2 days | Apply a cool, clean cloth; keep the area clean. | | **Mild fever (≥ 38 °C / 100.4 °F)** | 5–15 % after the first dose; 10–20 % after the second dose | 1‑2 days, peaks on day 1‑2 | Give acetaminophen or ibuprofen if the child is uncomfortable (avoid aspirin in children < 18 y). | | **Rash (measles‑like or “rose‑petal” rash)** | ≈ 5 % (usually a faint pink maculopapular rash) | 5‑10 days after vaccination; resolves without treatment | No specific therapy needed; keep skin clean. | | **Temporary joint pain or swelling (more common in adolescents/adults)** | < 1 % in children; up to 5 % in adults (especially females) | 1‑3 weeks, self‑limited | NSAIDs (ibuprofen) if needed; usually not severe. | | **Febrile seizures (convulsion caused by fever)** | ≈ 1
